Class Remove_Nodes_From_Linked_List

java.lang.Object
Remove_Nodes_From_Linked_List
public class Remove_Nodes_From_Linked_List extends Object
LeetCode 203: Remove Linked List Elements

Problem Description:
Given the head of a singly linked list and an integer val, remove all nodes of the linked list that have node.val == val, and return the head of the modified list.

Sample Input / Output: 


 Example 1:
 Input:  head = [1,2,6,3,4,5,6], val = 6
 Output: [1,2,3,4,5]

 Example 2:
 Input:  head = [], val = 1
 Output: []

 Example 3:
 Input:  head = [7,7,7,7], val = 7
 Output: []

Constraints:

  • 0 invalid input: '<'= n invalid input: '<'= 10^5 (n = number of nodes)
  • Node values are within 32-bit signed integer range

  • Method Details

    • removeElementsArrayList

      public ListNode removeElementsArrayList(ListNode head, int val)
      Removes all nodes equal to val by collecting kept values into an ArrayList, then rebuilding a new linked list from those values.
      Parameters:
      head - the head of the input list (may be null)
      val - the value to remove
      Returns:
      the head of the rebuilt list containing only nodes with value != val

      Method details:

      Approach 1: Using ArrayList (Filter → Rebuild)

      • Preserves original relative order of kept nodes.
      • Allocates new ListNode objects for the result.

      Detailed Steps:

      1. Traverse invalid input: '&' Collect:
        • Initialize an ArrayList<Integer> kept = new ArrayList<>();.
        • Walk the linked list from head to null.
        • For each node, if node.val != val add node.val to kept.
        Invariant: after this pass kept contains exactly the values to preserve, in the same order they appeared in the original list.
      2. Rebuild the linked list:
        • Create a dummy node ListNode dummy = new ListNode(0); and a tail pointer tail = dummy.
        • Iterate over kept and append new ListNode nodes in sequence.
        • Return dummy.next as the new head.
        Invariant: rebuilt list contains only values from kept in correct order.
      3. Edge cases:
        • If head == null → kept remains empty → returns null.
        • If every node matches val → kept empty → returns null.

      Approach 1 — Complexity:

      • Time: O(n) — one pass to collect values plus one pass to rebuild (linear overall).
      • Space (aux): O(n) — the ArrayList holds up to n values in worst-case.

    • removeElementsEfficient

      public ListNode removeElementsEfficient(ListNode head, int val)
      Removes all nodes equal to val in-place using a dummy sentinel and a single pass.
      Parameters:
      head - the head of the input list (may be null)
      val - the value to remove
      Returns:
      the head of the modified list (may be null)

      Method details:

      • Does not allocate additional list nodes other than the dummy.
      • Handles deletions at the head cleanly because of the dummy sentinel.
      • Careful not to advance the traversal pointer after a deletion so consecutive matches are handled.

      Approach 2: Efficient In-Place Deletion (Dummy + One Pass)

      Detailed Steps (very explicit):

      1. Create dummy sentinel:
        • ListNode dummy = new ListNode(0, head); — dummy.next points to the real head.
        • This unifies handling of deletions at the original head without special cases.
      2. Initialize traversal pointer:
        • Set ListNode current = dummy;.
        • We will examine current.next each iteration (look-ahead pattern).
        • Invariant: at the start of each loop, all nodes before current are already confirmed to be kept (none of them has value val).
      3. Loop: while (current.next != null):
        1. If current.next.val == val:
          • We need to delete current.next.
          • Perform current.next = current.next.next; which bypasses (unlinks) the node.
          • Important: Do NOT move current forward after deletion — the new current.next must be examined (handles consecutive nodes equal to val).
        2. Else (current.next.val != val):
          • No deletion needed for current.next, so advance: current = current.next;.
          • This preserves the invariant for the next iteration.
      4. Termination:
        • Loop ends when current.next == null — no more nodes to check.
        • Return dummy.next which points to the possibly-updated head.

      Why the "do not advance after delete" rule is required:

      • If you advanced current after unlinking, you might skip checking the next node which could also be equal to val. That would cause incorrect behavior on runs like [6,6,6,...].

      Approach 2 — Complexity:

      • Time: O(n) — each node is visited at most once; deletions are O(1).
      • Space: O(1) auxiliary — only a small fixed number of pointers are used (dummy, current).
